question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find the largest prime divisor of 11! + 12!
ground_truth: Since $12! = 12 \cdot 11!$, we can examine the sum better by factoring $11!$ out of both parts: $$ 11! + 12! = 11! + 12 \cdot 11! = 11!(1 + 12) = 11! \cdot 13. $$Since no prime greater than 11 divides $11!$, $\boxed{13}$ is the largest prime factor of $11! + 12!$.

question:
**Solution:**
The prime factorization of 11! + 12! is:

$$\begin{align*}
11! + 12! &= (11\times10\times\cdots\times2\times1) + (12\times11\times\cdots\times2\times1)\\
&= 11(10\times\cdots\times2\times1) + 11(12\times11\times\cdots\times2\times1)\\
&= 11(10\times\cdots\times2\times1 + 12\times11\times\cdots\times2\times1)\\
&= 11(10\times\cdots\times2\times1 + 2^2\times3\times11\times\cdots\times2\times1)\\
&= 11(10\times\cdots\times2\times1 + 2^2\times3\times11^2\times\cdots\times2\times1)\\
&= 11(10\times\cdots\times2\times1 + 2^2\times3\times11^2\times\cdots\times2\times1 + 2^2\times3\times11^3\times\cdots\times2\times1 + \cdots + 2^2\times3\times11^{11}\times\cdots\times2\times1)\\
&= 11(1 + 2\times3 + 2^2\times3\times11 + \cdots + 2^2\times3\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 2\times11 + 2^2\times11^2 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\

&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\

&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})\\
&= 11\times3\times(1 + 22 + 44 + \cdots + 2^2\times11^{10})

ground_truth: Since $12! = 12 \cdot 11!$, we can examine the sum better by factoring $11!$ out of both parts: $$ 11! + 12! = 11! + 12 \cdot 11! = 11!(1 + 12) = 11! \cdot 13. $$Since no prime greater than 11 divides $11!$, $\boxed{13}$ is the largest prime factor of $11! + 12!$.
